Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient has received a new diagnosis for a chronic condition and has many questions about managing it.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to enter the patient’s room. It was a text from my younger brother: “Can you call? I really need you.” He never asked for help unless it was serious. My heart twisted, but I slipped my phone back into my pocket. Inside, Mrs. Lee sat anxiously on the exam table, clutching the pamphlet I’d just given her about her new diagnosis. Her eyes searched mine, desperate for reassurance and clarity. As her doctor, I knew she needed my full attention, my patience, and my empathy to help her understand what this diagnosis meant for her life. But my mind kept drifting to my brother, wondering what he was going through, feeling the weight of his expectation that I’d be there for him, as I always had. I felt torn, the demands of being a good sister and a good doctor pulling me in opposite directions, each role asking for all of me at the same moment. My hands trembled slightly as I tried to focus on Mrs. Lee’s questions, my brother’s message echoing in my mind.
